PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: FAPESP-Temtico Mecanismos celulares e moleculares envolvidos no papel de neurotransmissores atpicos em transtornos neuropsiquitricos
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Nos ltimos 15 anos nosso grupo tem contribudo para a elucidao do papel do xido ntrico (NO) e endocanabinides (eCBs) em funes e disfunes do sistema nervoso central. Mostramos que a manipulao destes neurotransmissores atpicos modifica respostas comportamentais e autonmicas em modelos animais de ansiedade, depresso, psicoses e transtornos motores. Alm disso, tambm verificamos que um fitocanabinide, o canabidiol (CBD), que entre outros efeitos pode modificar a neurotransmisso mediada por eCBs, tambm capaz de alterar estas respostas tanto em animais de laboratrio como em humanos. O objetivo primrio do presente projeto, alm de dar continuidade a esta linha de pesquisa, abordando questes ainda no respondidas sobre os efeitos comportamentais de canabinides e NO (por exemplo, locais de ao e efeitos ainda no explorados, presena de possveis efeitos antiagressivos e antiparkinsonianos do CBD, etc.), procurar elucidar mecanismos celulares (alteraes neuroplsticas e imunolgicas) e moleculares (vias de sinalizao) responsveis por estes efeitos. Para isso empregaremos uma abordagem ampla, integrando tcnicas comportamentais e de registro autonmico com medidas de expresso gnica, atividade neuronial em grupos especficos, alteraes epigenticas e silenciamento gnico. Como resultado, alm de ampliar nosso conhecimento sobre estes sistemas (NO e eCBs) e os mecanismos de ao do CBD, iremos incorporar abordagens metodolgicas novas e importantes ao grupo bem como possibilitar a formao de recursos humanos nas reas de Neurocincia e Farmacologia.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Mecanismos celulares e moleculares envolvidos no papel de neurotransmissores atpicos em transtornos neuropsiquitricos

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Neuron-glia interaction in chronic degenerative pathologies of the central nervous system
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
The proposal encompasses three objectives we plan to fulfill based on the proposed objectives:
(1) Amplification and reinforcement of existing collaborations between Homburg and Ribeiro Pretostarted by a previous Probral project (2013-2015).
(2) Analysis of the different reactions of macroglial cells to different chronic pathological mousemodels, i.e. multiple sclerosis (MS), temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE) and Parkinson?s disease (PD).Task 2.1: Macroglial Ca2+ signaling and theirchanges after induction
of different chronic disease models in different brain regions.
Task 2.2: Function of the metabotropic GABABreceptors (GABABR) in different macroglial cells in chronicneuropathologies.
Task 2.3: Exploration of how pharmacologicalcannabinoid treatmentmodifies the progression of neuropathologies.
(3) Specific training of young academics by an exchange program with specific hands-on instructionsand top-of-the art methodologies.
(1) The proposal is based on an established, successful collaboration of Prof. Elaine Del-Bel at theUniversity of Sao Paulo, Campus of Ribeirao Preto (USP) and Prof. Frank Kirchhoff, University ofSaarland (USAAR), starting with the Probral project ?Differentiation and regeneration potential of glialcells in acute and chronic CNS pathologies? (2013-2015). Dr. Anja Scheller participated in the successfulexchange and became a group leader in Prof. Kirchhoff?s department supervising the BrazilianPhD students Fernando Resende and Lucianna Cartarozzi. To extend and strengthen the established
cooperation, we propose an intense exchange of young scientists (PhD students and postdocs)between USP and USAAR reenforcing the existing collaboration through common experiments andtraining workshops in Brazil and Germany.
(2.1) In recent years, it became clear that glial cells communicate with complex spatial and temporalpatterns of Ca2+ changes within subcellular compartments and throughout cellular networks. Therefore,we aim to answer how macroglial Ca2+ signals contribute to chronic brain pathologies, more preciselyin multiple sclerosis (MS), temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE) and Parkinson?s disease (PD). We willanalyse the role of macroglial Ca2+ signaling in the healthy and diseased brain by comparing variousbrain regions with in vivo and in situ Ca2+ imaging, using the murine pathology models well establishedin the respective partner labs (MS and TLE at USAAR/PD at USP). (2.2) We have identified that
deletion of GABABR affects Ca2+ signals in a mouse model of TLE and worsens remyelination in anMS model. To better understand heterogeneous glial Ca2+ signaling we will use conditional cell-typespecific inducible GABABR knockout mice and evaluate the impact of GABABR in disease models. Inaddition, we will study differences of glial Ca2+ signaling in different brain regions (cortex, striatum andspinal cord) impacted in the respective disease models. Most PD patients receive L-DOPA (L-3,4- Dihydroxyphenylalanin, Levodopa) and eventually develop debilitating hyperkinetic involuntary movements(dyskinesia), associated with dynamic changes in primary motor cortex (PMC) physiology. Nopublished studies yet, investigate in vivo neurotransmitter release in the PMC during dyskinesia. LDOPAadministration reduced glutamate efflux and enhanced GABA efflux in the PMC, coincident withthe emergence of dyskinetic behaviors inPD rats. Dyskinesia was reduced by local PMC modulation ofD1, AMPA, and GABAA receptors, providing preclinical support that interference in PMC signaling
(pharmacologically or with cortical stimulation) is a therapeutic approach to treat debilitating dyskinesias.We will study the function of glial GABABR on induced dyskinesia while observing neuronalactivity with newly developed surface electrodes. (2.3) Cannabinoids have a multitude of effectsincluding neuroprotection with beneficial outcome
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES:
Glial Heterogeneity State of the art and preliminary work 

State of the art 
Astrocytes have originally been described as a main population of neuroglia in the central nervous system (CNS). In the past years numerous studies highlighted their role in brain function, in particular their contribution to synaptogenesis, synaptic transmission and its plasticity, ion homeostasis, trophic regulation and blood-brain barrier formation to name a few (for extensive review: Kettenmann and Ransom, 2013). Already since the time of Golgi and Cajal an extended degree of morphological diversities was found to exist throughout the various brain regions, compare e.g. Bergmann glia with cortical grey matter protoplasmic astrocytes or callosal white matter astrocytes. Coupling morphological phenotypes with functional properties suggests the existence of distinct subtypes of astrocytes that have to be equipped with a distinct molecular repertoire of signaling molecules and pathways. However, it has remained completely enigmatic whether morphologically or functionally identified subsets of astrocytes are still plastic and interchangeable. Linking molecular and functional heterogeneity of astrocytes has become one of the most important questions among glial biologists. 

The main signaling language astrocytes are using is encoded in changes of their intracellular Ca2+ activity ([Ca2+]i). The intracellular Ca2+ is not only a signaling molecule; it is also a major determinant of plastic cell morphology by its modulatory binding to various components of the cytoskeleton. And indeed, the astrocyte membrane is equipped with a plethora of receptors, ion channels and transporters that are involved in an intricate network of pathways to regulate cytoplasmic Ca2+. By virtue of these membrane-bound signaling system astrocytes can sense all type of neurotransmitters activating a diversity of ionotropic or metabotropic receptors, e.g. for ATP, dopamine, glutamate, GABA, serotonin, histamine, various growth factors and peptide hormones. In addition, astrocytes can express Ca2+ channels (e.g. TRP channels) that can be regulated by cytoplasmic second messengers. Plasma-membrane bound Ca2+ ATPases and sodium-dependent Ca2+ transporters are other molecules that contribute to the cellular Ca2+ signaling. Main cell biological processes in astrocytes that have been identified to be crucially determined by Ca2+ are vesicular release of transmitters, gene transcription, cytoskeleton dynamics and proteolysis. 
Astrocyte function can only be understood by taking its complex morphology into account. Recently, a unifying nomenclature for astrocyte processes has been suggested (Tong et al., 2013). Branches are the up to 10 major processes with 1 to 2 μm in diameter that emanate from the soma, branchlets are numerous finer secondary, tertiary and higher order structures of submicrometer scale emanating from the branches and leaflets are the very terminal extensions on the tens of nanometer scale that contact synapses. Finally, endfeet are specialized distal extensions of astrocytes that contact the vasculature. Depending on the subcellular location of membrane receptors and ion channels together with intracellular Ca2+ storing compartments such as the endoplasmic reticulum and mitochondria a complex pattern of temporal and spatial Ca2+ fluctuations control the diversity of astroglial properties that will be instrumental for brain function. 
So far, few but excellent studies have shed light onto the complexity of spontaneous, i.e. without experimentator-evoked stimulation, Ca2+ signals. By using in vivo two-photon laser-scanning microscopy (2P-LSM) of awake and behaving mouse three types of extended Ca2+ signals could be identified in Bergmann glia of the mouse cerebellum (Nimmerjahn et al., 2009). Ca2+ waves and bursts have also been detected in cortical astrocytes of moving mi

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Proc. FAPESP 2002/13197-2 Auxilio Pesquisa - Projeto Tematico
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
Subprojeto 4a. Regies cerebrais envolvidas na induo de catalepsia. Anlise da induo de protena Fos no crebro de camundongos aps a administrao de inibidor da NOS, haloperidol e fentanil. Induo da protena Fos no crebro de cobaias, ratos e camundongos por Pentilenotetrazol. O trabalho est em fase de reviso para ser submetido publicao.

Sub-Projeto 4b. Modulao da catalepsia induzida por inibidores da NOS. Avaliamos o efeito de drogas que so utilizadas no tratamento de pacientes com doena de Parkinson sobre a catalepsia induzida por L-NOARG. Nossos resultados mostram que a administrao de antagonistas muscarnicos (atropina e biperideno) antagonizaram a catalepsia induzida por L-NOARG, o que no ocorre com droga antimuscarnica que no cruza a barreira hemato-enceflica, a metil-atropina. LDOPA e apomorfina inibiram a catalepsia inibida por L-NOARG, de forma dose dependente. Tambm verificamos os efeitos da amantadina e memantina (1-amino-3,5-dimethyladamantane), ambas antagonistas no competitivos de receptores N-methyl-D-Aspartato. A amantadina no modificou o efeito do L-NOARG e a memantina a inibiu. Houve interao entre os fatores tratamento vs tempo, com todos os anti-psicticos atpicos utilizados: Ziprasidona; Aripiprazole; Clozapina; Olanzapina. Olanzapina (1-3 mg/kg) bloqueou o efeito catalptico do L-NOARG. Estamos analisando estes efeitos sobre a catalepsia induzida por 7NI. Um artigo est em fase de redao a ser enviado para o Neuropsychopharmacology Antipsychotic typical and atypical and antiparkinsonian drugs modulated catalepsy induced by nitric oxide synthase inhibitors in mice. E. A Del Bel, M.B Echeverry, F.S. Guimares, CA Silva.

Subprojeto 4c. Efeito da administrao icv de inibidores da NOS em camundongos. Analisamos a induo de catalepsia em camundongos aps a aplicao de inibidores da sntese de NO (LNOARG e 7NIO), de inibidores da guanilato ciclase (ODQ e Azul de metileno), via intracerebroventricular. As drogas

Federation of Caribean and Latinamerican Neurosciences society

VINCULOS.OUTRAS-INFORMACOES:
The purpose of this letter is to introduce the new Executive board of the Federation of Neuroscience Societies in Latin America, the Caribbean and the Iberian Peninsula (FALAN) to FENS and their Society members. They were elected for a two years term starting on March 2018. It is formed by:
Elaine Del-Bel: President (University of Sao Paulo- Brazil) 
Patricia Cassina: Vice-President (Universidad de La Republica-Uruguay) 
Gloria Patricia Cardona: Secretary (University of Antioquia-Medellin- Colombia)
Ana Beln Elgoyen: Scientific Committee Chair (University of Buenos Aires Argentina) 
Paola Haeger: Treasurer (Universidad Catlica del Norte, Coquimbo, Chile)
FALAN represents several thousand neuroscientists working in the region working succefully in compass with IBRO-LARC committee. FALAN starts as a federation on 5th of July 2013 representing several thousand neuroscientists working in the region. Last FALAN meeting (2016-Buenos Aires Argentina) congregates 1.189 participants, most from Latin America. Particularly FALAN is interested in creating the conditions for a synergic interaction among the society members and with other Neuroscience Societies around the world. Our short-term goals include to introduce our students support our scientific community to reach and keep excellence in neuroscience and the organization of seminars, courses and advance schools. 
Please let us know if you have any suggestion for our neuroscientific agenda. Also, we would like to invite you to submit any news from IBRO to be published at the FALAN home page.

On behalf of the Trustees of The Physiological Society, we would like to congratulate you on becoming a Fellow of The Society. This recognises your continuous and active service to The Society and to our discipline. You are now eligible to use the FPhysiol designation.
 
A list of all new Fellows will be published on The Society?s website and in a future edition of Physiology News.
 
You are supporting the next generation of physiologists, with the additional membership fee being set aside to develop and fund a number of Early Career Researcher initiatives.
 
Please do not hesitate to contact the Membership Services Team should you have any queries.
Once again, many congratulations on your Fellowship.
 
With very best wishes,
 
David Eisner
President
 
Rachel Tribe
Chair, Membership & Grants Committee

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: INCT CNPQ-FAPESP UMA ABORDAGEM TRANSLACIONAL DO ESTUDO DO CANABIDIOL: UMA SUBSTNCIA COM AMPLO ESPECTRO DE AO NO TRATAMENTO DOS TRANSTORNOS NEUROPSIQUITRICOS
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
Os transtornos mentais, comportamentais e neurolgicos so muito comuns, afetando mais de 30% da populao em
dada fase da sua vida. Isto acarreta em enormes custos econmicos diretos e indiretos, clara reduo nos anos de vida ajustados
para incapacidades e pior qualidade de vida para pacientes e seus familiares. Apesar dos avanos na neurocincia e na medicina do
comportamento, de modo geral, a maior parte das medicaes para o tratamento apresentam importantes efeitos colaterais,
sendo que algumas apresentam potencial de dependncia, tolerncia, sedao e problemas na descontinuao. Entretanto,
ainda mais importante, que, de modo geral, uma parcela substancial dos pacientes com transtornos neuropsiquitricos (entre
3o- e 50%) no respondem plenamente aos tratamentos farmacolgicos disponveis atualmente, com significativa taxa de
refratariedade e manuteno de sintomas. Dessa forma, existe uma grande necessidade na busca de novas medicaes, que
atuem em novos sistemas e receptores, que apresentem rpido incio da ao, menos efeitos colaterais adversos e,
especialmente, maior eficcia teraputica.
A planta Cannabis Sativa possui mais do que 400 componentes, sendo que aproximadamente 80 destes so
componentes canabinides, como o canabidiol (CBD), que constitui at 40% dos extratos da planta, e desprovido dos efeitos
psicolgicos tpicos da cannabis em humanos. O grupo sediado na Faculdade de Medicina de Ribeiro Preto-USP (FMRP-USP),
 um dos grupos pioneiros no uso experimental e clnico de canabinoides de modo geral,e do canabidiol (CBD) em particular.
Nesse sentido, temos produzido crescente nmero de publicaes cientficas com resultados bastante promissores
demonstrando efeitos teraputicos do CBD em diversos modelos animais de transtornos neuropsiquitricos, bem como em
ensaios clnicos com pacientes, como os efeitos ansiolticos, antidepressivos e antipsicticos. Do mesmo modo, o grupo realiza
pesquisas bsicas e clnicas sobre outros efeitos teraputicos do CBD, porm agora tambm procurando ampliar a investigao
do seu potencial para epilepsia, dependncia e abuso de substncias como a cocana na forma de ?crack?, fobia social, estresse
ps-traumtico, transtorno obsessivo compulsivo, transtornos do sono e Parkinson. Igualmente, pretendemos realizar estudos
do CBD no seu efeito neuroprotetor e antioxidante.
Em 2010 o Prof. Raphael Mechoulam, responsvel pelo isolamento e sntese dos principais canabinides (incluindo o
THC em 1964 e CBD em 1963) e pela descoberta do sistema endocanabinide (receptor CB1 em 1989 e anandamida em 1992),
procurou o nosso grupo para desenvolver anlogos sintticos patenteveis do CBD. Os derivados fluorados do CBD (HU474,
HU475, HU485, CBD-DMH) foram criados com a perspectiva de se encontrar compostos com propriedades semelhantes s do
CBD, porm mais potentes, com composio estvel e com igual perfil de segurana e ausncia de toxicidade, o que j
demonstramos em animais. Assim, no presente ano de 2014 o grupo realizou depsito de patente internacional (US no. Reg.
61750043; Jan/2014) desses compostos. Isto demonstra a necessidade de ampliar o desenvolvimento tanto do CBD como dos
seus anlogos fluorados. Estes apresentam forte potencial de transferncia para o setor produtivo para comercializao e
possibilidade de benefcio para pacientes com amplo espectro de transtornos neuropsiquitricos. Dessa forma, nossos
objetivos principais so realizar estudos clnicos e pr-clnicos com o tanto do CBD como dos seus derivados sintticos
fluorados (HU474, HU475, HU485, CBD-DMH):
1. Estudos Pr-clnicos: Uso de modelos animais de ansiedade, estresse, depresso, dependncia de crack/cocana,
psicose, epilepsia, analgesia e neuroproteo para avaliao dos mecanismos de ao e de parmetros comportamentais,

PARTICIPACAO-EM-PROJETO.NOME-ORGAO: Faculdade de medicina de Ribeirao Preto USP

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: INCT CNPQ-FAPESP 465458/2014-9 Uma abordagem translacional do estudo do canabidiol: uma substncia com amplo espectro de ao nos transtornos neuropsiquitricos
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Os transtornos mentais, comportamentais e neurolgicos so muito comuns, afetando mais de 30% da populao em dada fase da sua vida. Isto acarreta em enormes custos econmicos diretos e indiretos, clara reduo nos anos de vida ajustados para incapacidades e pior qualidade de vida para pacientes e seus familiares. Apesar dos avanos na neurocincia e na medicina do comportamento, de modo geral, a maior parte das medicaes para o tratamento apresentam importantes efeitos colaterais, sendo que algumas apresentam potencial de dependncia, tolerncia, sedao e problemas na descontinuao. Entretanto, ainda mais importante, que, de modo geral, uma parcela substancial dos pacientes com transtornos neuropsiquitricos (entre 3o- e 50%) no respondem plenamente aos tratamentos farmacolgicos disponveis atualmente, com significativa taxa de refratariedade e manuteno de sintomas. Dessa forma, existe uma grande necessidade na busca de novas medicaes, que atuem em novos sistemas e receptores, que apresentem rpido incio da ao, menos efeitos colaterais adversos e, especialmente, maior eficcia teraputica. A planta Cannabis Sativa possui mais do que 400 componentes, sendo que aproximadamente 80 destes so componentes canabinides, como o canabidiol (CBD), que constitui at 40% dos extratos da planta, e desprovido dos efeitos psicolgicos tpicos da cannabis em humanos. O grupo sediado na Faculdade de Medicina de Ribeiro Preto-USP (FMRP-USP), um dos grupos pioneiros no uso experimental e clnico de canabinoides de modo geral,e do canabidiol (CBD) em particular. Nesse sentido, temos produzido crescente nmero de publicaes cientficas com resultados bastante promissores demonstrando efeitos teraputicos do CBD em diversos modelos animais de transtornos neuropsiquitricos, bem como em ensaios clnicos com pacientes, como os efeitos ansiolticos, antidepressivos e antipsicticos. Do mesmo modo, o grupo realiza pesquisas bsicas e clnicas sobre outros efeitos teraputicos do CBD, porm agora tambm procurando ampliar a investigao do seu potencial para epilepsia, dependncia e abuso de substncias como a cocana na forma de ?crack?, fobia social, estresse ps-traumtico, transtorno obsessivo compulsivo, transtornos do sono e Parkinson. Igualmente, pretendemos realizar estudos do CBD no seu efeito neuroprotetor e antioxidante. Em 2010 o Prof. Raphael Mechoulam, responsvel pelo isolamento e sntese dos principais canabinides (incluindo o THC em 1964 e CBD em 1963) e pela descoberta do sistema endocanabinide (receptor CB1 em 1989 e anandamida em 1992), procurou o nosso grupo para desenvolver anlogos sintticos patenteveis do CBD. Os derivados fluorados do CBD (HU474, HU475, HU485, CBD-DMH) foram criados com a perspectiva de se encontrar compostos com propriedades semelhantes s do CBD, porm mais potentes, com composio estvel e com igual perfil de segurana e ausncia de toxicidade, o que j demonstramos em animais. Assim, no presente ano de 2014 o grupo realizou depsito de patente internacional (US no. Reg. 61750043; Jan/2014) desses compostos. Isto demonstra a necessidade de ampliar o desenvolvimento tanto do CBD como dos seus anlogos fluorados. Estes apresentam forte potencial de transferncia para o setor produtivo para comercializao e possibilidade de benefcio para pacientes com amplo espectro de transtornos neuropsiquitricos. Dessa forma, nossos objetivos principais so realizar estudos clnicos e pr-clnicos com o tanto do CBD como dos seus derivados sintticos fluorados (HU474, HU475, HU485, CBD-DMH): 1. Estudos Pr-clnicos: Uso de modelos animais de ansiedade, estresse, depresso, dependncia de crack/cocana, psicose, epilepsia, analgesia e neuroproteo para avaliao dos mecanismos de ao e de parmetros comportamentais, neuroplsticos, moleculares, estruturais e epigenticos envolvidos em seus efeitos

VINCULOS.OUTRAS-INFORMACOES:
On behalf of the Trustees of The Physiological Society, we would like to congratulate you on becoming a Fellow of The Society. This recognises your continuous and active service to The Society and to our discipline. You are now eligible to use the FPhysiol designation.
 
A list of all new Fellows will be published on The Society?s website and in a future edition of Physiology News.
 
You are supporting the next generation of physiologists, with the additional membership fee being set aside to develop and fund a number of Early Career Researcher initiatives.
 
Please do not hesitate to contact the Membership Services Team should you have any queries.
Once again, many congratulations on your Fellowship.
 
With very best wishes,
 
David Eisner
President
 
Rachel Tribe
Chair, Membership & Grants Committee

VINCULOS.OUTRAS-INFORMACOES:
On behalf of SfN and WWN, thank you for agreeing to be part of the ?Self-Advocacy Social: Impact of Culture, Policies and Religion?.
 invitation to the SfN-WWN Social on Monday January 11th, 2021 at 9:00am.

As you already know, The ALBA Network aims to promote equality and diversity in brain sciences.

On behalf of Prof. Carmen Sandi, Chair of the ALBA Steering Committee (ASC), I would like to officially invite you to be a member of our Committee. We believe your participation and input would be a great asset for the development of a strong and effective vision and mission for this network.

The Alba Steering Committee is composed of women and men involved in research, education, communication and advocacy in brain sciences. You can already find information on the ASC and the Network on www.alba.network

Acute and Delayed Restraint Stress-Induced Changes in Nitric Oxide Producing Neurons in Limbic Regions
Cannabidiol Increases Fos Expression in the Nucleus Accumbens But Not in the Dorsal Striatum
Combined Treatment of Ascorbic Acid or Alpha-Tocopherol With Dopamine Receptor Antagonist Or Nitric Oxide Synthase Inhibitor Potentiates Cataleptic Effect In Mice

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Rationale: Drugs that decrease dopamine (DA) neurotransmission in the striatum induce catalepsy in rodents and Parkinson disease-like symptoms in humans. Nitric oxide synthase (NOS) inhibitors interfere with motor activity, disrupting rodent exploratory behavior and inducing catalepsy. Catalepsy induced by NOS inhibitors probably involves striatal dopamine-mediated neurotransmission. Antioxidants such as ascorbic acid (vitamin C) and alpha-tocopherol (vitamin E) have also been shown to interfere with movement modulation and the DA system.
Objective: To investigate if the antioxidants vitamins C and E would influence the catalepsy produced by haloperidol (Hal) and NOS inhibitors.
Methods: The effects of the following treatments on catalepsy were examined in the hanging-bar test on male Swiss mice (25-30g): i. vitamin C (30-1000 mg/kg) X Hal (1 mg/kg); ii. vitamin C (90-1000 mg/kg) X NG-nitro-L-arginine (LNOARG, 10 and 40 mg/kg); iii. vitamin C (300 mg/kg) X NG-nitro-L-arginine methylester (LNAME, 20-80 mg/kg); iv. vitamin C (300 mg/kg) X 7-nitroindazole (7NI, 3-50 mg/kg); v. vitamin C (90 mg/kg IP) X LNOARG (40 mg/kg twice a day during 4 days- sub-chronic effect); vi. vitamin E (3-100 mg/kg X Hal (1 mg/kg) and vii. vitamin E (3-100 mg/kg) X LNOARG (40 mg/kg). 
Results: Vitamin C enhanced the catalepsy produced by NOS inhibitors and Hal. Treatment with vitamin C did not affect tolerance to LNOARG cataleptic effect induced by sub-chronic treatment. Vitamin E potentiated the catalepsy induced by LNOARG at all doses, but only at the dose of 100 mg/kg, the catalepsy induced by Hal. Moreover, Vitamin C (1000mg/kg) and Vitamin E (10-100 mg/kg) induced catalepsy by themselves.
Conclusions: The results suggest that antioxidants such as vitamins C and E can enhance the cataleptic effect induced by inhibition of nitric oxide (NO) formation or by antagonism of DA receptors. Further studies are needed to assess possible clinical implications of these findings.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Role of Nitric Oxide on Motor Behaviour

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: 1. The present review paper describes results indicating the influence of nitric oxide (NO) on motor control. Our last studies showed that systemic injections of low doses of inhibitors of NO synthase (NOS), the enzyme responsible for NO formation, induce anxiolytic effects in the elevated plus maze whereas higher doses decreasemaze exploration. Also, NOS inhibitors decrease locomotion and rearing in an open field arena. 2. These results may involve motor effects of this compounds, since inhibitors of NOS, NG-nitro-L-arginine (L-NOARG), NG-nitro-L-arginine methylester (L-NAME), NGmonomethyl- L-arginine (L-NMMA), and 7-Nitroindazole (7-NIO), induced catalepsy in mice. This effect was also found in rats after systemic, intracebroventricular or intrastriata administration. 3. Acute administration of L-NOARG has an additive cataleptic effect with haloperidol, a dopamine D2 antagonist. The catalepsy is also potentiated byWAY 100135 (5-HT1a receptor antagonist), ketanserin (5HT2a and alfa1 adrenergic receptor antagonist), and ritanserin (5-HT2a and 5HT2c receptor antagonist). Atropine sulfate and biperiden, antimuscarinic drugs, block L-NOARG-induced catalepsy in mice. 4. L-NOARG subchronic administration inmice induces rapid tolerance (3 days) to itscataleptic effects. It also produces cross-tolerance to haloperidol-induced catalepsy. Ater subchronic L-NOARG treatment there is an increase in the density NADPH-d positive neurons in the dorsal part of nucleus caudate-putamen, nucleus accumbens, and tegmental pedunculupontinus nucleus. In contrast, this treatment decreases NADPH-d neuronal number in the substantia nigra compacta. 5. Considering these results we suggest that (i) NO may modulate motor behavior, probably by interfering with dopaminergic, serotonergic, and cholinergic neurotransmission in the striatum; (ii) Subchronic NO synthesis inhibition induces plastic changes in NO producing neurons in brain areas related to motor control and and causes cross-tolerance

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Restrained Stress Induces B-Amyloid Precursor Protein mRNA Expression in the Rat Basolateral Amygdala

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The beta amyloid protein precursor (beta APP) is well-conserved across different species and may fulfil important physiological functions within the central nervous system. Studies have shown the involvement of APP isoforms in some neurodegeneration process like Alzheimer's disease, neuronal damage by kainic acid (KA), epilepsy by tetanus toxin, among others. Despite intense interest, there is limited knowledge about their physiological function. APP695 mRNA is the predominant form of APP mRNA in rat brain while APP770 mRNA but are less than 10% of APP mRNA in rat brain. Restraint stress has been shown to induce behavioural and brain morphological changes. This observation led us to examine by in situ hybridization (ISH) the involvement of the APP695 and APP770 mRNA isoforms levels induced by acute or chronic stress episodes in hippocampus and amygdala. The mRNA expression was increased in the basolateral amygdaloid nuclei after 6 hours of restraint for one or 21 days for APP695 isoform. No changes was observed either in the hippocampus or in the APP770 mRNA isoforms in both areas examined. In conclusion, restraint stress resulted in isoform selective and region-specific alterations in APP695 isoform mRNA density, some of which may contribute to the altered stress response. The mechanisms underlying these changes and their relationship to the neurodegenerative/neuroprotector process are under intense scrutiny. The functional significance of the changes in APP mRNA density described in this study awaits elucidation.

Single Intranasal Administration of 1-Methyl-4-Phenyl-1,2,3,6-Tetrahydropyridine in C57BL/6 Mice Models Early Preclinical Phase of Parkinson?s Disease.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Many studies have shown that deficits in olfactory and cognitive functions precede the classical motor symptoms seen in Parkinson?s disease (PD) and that olfactory testing may contribute to the early diagnosis of this disorder. Although the primary cause of PD is still unknown, epidemiological studies have revealed that its incidence is increased in consequence of exposure to certain environmental toxins. In this study, most of the impairments presented by C57BL/6 mice infused with a single intranasal (i.n.) administration of the proneurotoxin 1-methyl-4-phe- nyl-1,2,3,6-tetrahydropyridine (MPTP) (1 mg/nostril) were similar to those observed during the early phase of PD, when a moderate loss of nigral dopamine neurons results in olfactory and memory deficits with no major motor impairments. Such infusion decreased the levels of the
26 enzyme tyrosine hydroxylase in the olfactory bulb, striatum,and substantia nigra by means of apoptotic mechanisms, reducing dopamine concentration in different brain structures such as olfactory bulb, striatum, and prefrontal cortex, but not in the hippocampus. These findings reinforce the notion that the olfactory system represents a particularly sensitive route for the transport of neurotoxins into the central nervous system that may be related to the etiology of PD. These results also provide new insights in experimental models of PD, indicating that the i.n. administration of MPTP represents a valuable mouse model for the study of the early stages of PD and for testing new therapeutic strategies to restore sensorial and cognitive processes in PD.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Melatonin effect on experimental traumatic compression of the spinal cord
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Melatonin effect on experimental traumatic compression of the spinal cord

DETALHAMENTO-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-PERIODICO-OU-REVISTA: Brazilian Journal of Medical and Biological Research (Impresso)

AUTORES.NOME-COMPLETO-DO-AUTOR: Elaine Aparecida Del Bel Belluz Guimaraes

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Spinal cord injury is a terrible condition with no effective therapies available. In this study we looked the effect of melatonin in traumatic compression of spinal cord. Sixty male adult Wistar rats were divided into three experimental groups: sham operated, 35% and 50% spinal cord compression with a polycarbonate rod spacer. Each group was sub-divided and each one received injection of vehicle or melatonin (2.5 mg/kg, i.p.), 5 minutes, 1, 2, 3, and 4 hours after injury. Weekly, functional recovery was monitored by open field test, Basso, Beattie and Bresnahan motor scale and inclined plane test. Histological changes of damaged spinal cord were examined 35 days after injury. Motor scores were progressively lower as spacer size increased according to the motor scale and inclined plane test evaluation, in all periods of assessment. Results from both tests were highly correlated. Open field test presented similar results with less pronounced difference between the groups 35% and 50%. Injured groups presented functional recovery on time more evident at the first and second weeks. Animals receiving melatonin treatment presented more pronounced functional recovery than saline animals as measured by motor scale or inclined plane. NADPH-d histochemistry revealed integrity of the spinal cord thoracic segment in sham operated and following laminectomy. It also confirmed the severity of the lesion after spinal cord narrowing. In conclusion our results as demonstrated by the experimental traumatic compression of the spinal cord, corroborated the hypothesis of melatonin with its protective effect may be used in clinical practice.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Anti-dyskinetic effect of the neuronal nitric oxide synthase inhibitor is linked to decrease of FosB/DeltaFosB expression
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Anti-dyskinetic effect of the neuronal nitric oxide synthase inhibitor is linked to decrease of FosB/DeltaFosB expression

AUTORES.NOME-COMPLETO-DO-AUTOR: Elaine Aparecida Del Bel Belluz Guimaraes

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: phenylalanine (L-DOPA) treatment develop abnormal involuntary movements called dyskinesia. We demonstrated that nitric oxide synthase (NOS) inhibitors mitigate L-DOPA-induced dyskinesia in rodents. The aim of the present study was to verify if the in vivo preferential neuronal NOS (nNOS) inhibitor 7-Nitroindazole (7-NI) affect the expression of the transcription factor FosB/ΔFosB in the lesioned striatum, an indicator of neuronal activity associated with dyskinesia. Male Wistar rats with unilateral microinjection (medial forebrain bundle) of either the neurotoxin 6- hydroxidopamine (6-OHDA; n=4-6/group) or saline (sham; n=6/group) were provided with L-DOPA (30 mg/kg plus benserazide 7.5 mg/kg/day, oral gavage), once a day during 22 days. 6-OHDA-lesioned animals developed abnormal involuntary movements (AIMs) classified as axial, limb, orofacial and locomotive dyskinesia and presented FosB/ΔFosB increase in the dopamine-depleted striatum. Administration of 7-NI (30 mg/kg, i.p.), 30 min prior to L-DOPA reduced the severity of AIMs (≈65% for axial, limb and orofacial and 74% for locomotive AIMs scores), without interfering with the rotarod performance. Simultaneously, 7-NI attenuated the expression of FosB/ΔFosB in dopamine-depleted striatum (≈65% in medial and ≈54% in lateral striatum, bregma 0.48 mm). FosB/ΔFosB expression in lateral striatum was correlated with L-DOPA-induced dyskinesia. The findings described here corroborate a new approach to the management of L-DOPA-therapy in Parkinson's disease (PD) treatment.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Experimental model of intervertebral disc degeneration by needle puncture in Wistar rats
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Experimental model of intervertebral disc degeneration by needle puncture in Wistar rats

DETALHAMENTO-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-PERIODICO-OU-REVISTA: Brazilian Journal of Medical and Biological Research (Impresso)

AUTORES.NOME-COMPLETO-DO-AUTOR: Elaine Aparecida Del Bel Belluz Guimaraes

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: At present, the treatment of discogenic back pain is mainly empirical and aimed at relieving symptoms. Animal models of intervertebral disc degeneration may play an important role in clarifying the physiopathological mechanisms and testing novel therapeutic strategies. The objective of this study was to describe a needle puncture model using Wistar rats and to confirm radiography, magnetic resonance and histology as reliable evaluating tools. Adult male Wistar rats were anesthetized and submitted to percutaneous disc puncture with a 20-gauge needle on levels 6-7 and 8-9 of the coccygeal vertebrae. The needle was inserted into the discs guided by fluoroscopy and its tip was positioned crossing the nucleus pulposus up to the contralateral annulus fibrosus, rotated 360 twice, and held for 30 seconds. To grade the severity of intervertebral disc degeneration we measured the intervertebral disc height from radiographic analyses 7 or 30 days after the injury, and the signal intensity T2-weigthed magnetic resonance imaging. Histological analysis was performed with hematoxylin- eosin and collagen fiber orientation using picrosirius red staining and polarized microscopy. Imaging and histological score analyses revealed significant disc degeneration both 7 and 30 days after the lesion. Interobserver histological evaluation showed significant agreement. There was a significant positive correlation between histological score and intervertebral disc height 7 or 30 days after the lesion. We conclude that tail disc puncture method may address the fundamental mechanisms of discogenic pain. On this basis, Wistar rats were validated as an appropriate species to estimate the physiopathology and therapy of degenerative disc disease.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Doxycycline restrains glia and confers neuroprotection in a 6-OHDA Parkinson model
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Doxycycline restrains glia and confers neuroprotection in a 6-OHDA Parkinson model

AUTORES.NOME-COMPLETO-DO-AUTOR: Elaine Aparecida Del Bel Belluz Guimaraes

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Manuscript # GLIA-00394-2012 
6-hydroxydopamine (6-OHDA) damages the nigrostriatal dopaminergic pathway as seen in Parkinson's disease (PD), a common chronic neurodegenerative disorder with no effective protective treatment. PD is characterized by the loss of dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra (SN), decreased striatal dopamine levels, and consequent extrapyramidal motor dysfunction. Consistent with a role of glial cells in PD neurodegeneration, here we show that doxycycline, an approved tetracycline derivative that inhibits glial activation independently of its antimicrobial properties, mitigates the demise of nigrostriatal dopaminergic neurons induced by stereotactically 6-OHDA microinjection into unilateral striatum. C57BL/6N male mice were randomly divided into experimental groups (6-OHDA) and respective controls (saline) with and without doxyxycline administration. The damage to the dopaminergic neurons in SN following 6-OHDA-microinjection was observed by using tyrosine hydroxylase-positive immunoreactive neuronal numbers. The two specific antibodies macrophage antigen-1 and glial fibrillary acid protein were used to detect the changes in morphology and the numbers of microglia and astrocytes, respectively. We report here that, in the 6-OHDA mouse model of PD, doxycycline in a dose that both induces/represses conditional transgene expression in the tetracycline system (1) mitigates the loss of dopaminergic cell bodies in the SN pars compacta and of nerve terminals in the striatum, (2) prevents microglial response in the globus pallidus and substantia nigra with minimal effects on the astrocytic activation in the striatum and globus pallidus. Our results suggest that doxycycline blocks 6-OHDA neurotoxicity in vivo by inhibiting microglial expression. Neuroprotective doxycycline may be effective in preventing or slowing the progression of PD and other neurodegenerative diseases.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Are cyclooxygenase-2 and nitric oxide involved in the dyskinesia of Parkinson's disease induced by L-DOPA?
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Are cyclooxygenase-2 and nitric oxide involved in the dyskinesia of Parkinson's disease induced by L-DOPA?

DETALHAMENTO-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-PERIODICO-OU-REVISTA: Philosophical Transactions - Royal Society. Biological Sciences (Print)

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Abstract

Inflammatory mechanisms are proposed to play a role in L-DOPA-induced dyskinesia. Cyclooxygenase-2 (COX2) contributes to inflammation pathways in the periphery and is constitutively expressed in the central nervous system. Considering that inhibition of nitric oxide (NO) formation attenuates L-DOPA-induced dyskinesia, this study aimed at investigating if a NO synthase (NOS) inhibitor would change COX2 brain expression in animals with L-DOPA-induced dyskinesia. To this aim, male Wistar rats received unilateral 6-hydroxydopamine microinjection into the medial forebrain bundle were treated daily with L-DOPA (21 days) combined with 7-nitroindazole or vehicle. All hemi-Parkinsonian rats receiving L-DOPA showed dyskinesia. They also presented increased neuronal COX2 immunoreactivity in the dopamine-depleted dorsal striatum that was directly correlated with dyskinesia severity. Striatal COX2 co-localized with choline-acetyltransferase, calbindin and DARPP-32 (dopamine-cAMP-regulated phosphoprotein-32), neuronal markers of GABAergic neurons. NOS inhibition prevented L-DOPA-induced dyskinesia and COX2 increased expression in the dorsal striatum. These results suggest that increased COX2 expression after L-DOPA long-term treatment in Parkinsonian-like rats could contribute to the development of dyskinesia.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES:
Abstract

Inflammatory mechanisms are proposed to play a role in L-DOPA-induced dyskinesia. Cyclooxygenase-2 (COX2) contributes to inflammation pathways in the periphery and is constitutively expressed in the central nervous system. Considering that inhibition of nitric oxide (NO) formation attenuates L-DOPA-induced dyskinesia, this study aimed at investigating if a NO synthase (NOS) inhibitor would change COX2 brain expression in animals with L-DOPA-induced dyskinesia. To this aim, male Wistar rats received unilateral 6-hydroxydopamine microinjection into the medial forebrain bundle were treated daily with L-DOPA (21 days) combined with 7-nitroindazole or vehicle. All hemi-Parkinsonian rats receiving L-DOPA showed dyskinesia. They also presented increased neuronal COX2 immunoreactivity in the dopamine-depleted dorsal striatum that was directly correlated with dyskinesia severity. Striatal COX2 co-localized with choline-acetyltransferase, calbindin and DARPP-32 (dopamine-cAMP-regulated phosphoprotein-32), neuronal markers of GABAergic neurons. NOS inhibition prevented L-DOPA-induced dyskinesia and COX2 increased expression in the dorsal striatum. These results suggest that increased COX2 expression after L-DOPA long-term treatment in Parkinsonian-like rats could contribute to the development of dyskinesia.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Nitric oxide, a new player in l-dopa-induced dyskinesia?

AUTORES.NOME-COMPLETO-DO-AUTOR: Elaine Aparecida Del Bel Belluz Guimaraes

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: L-3,4-Dihydroxyphenylalanine (L-DOPA) remains the most effective symptomatic treatment of Parkinson?s disease (PD). However, the long-term use of L-DOPA causes, in combination with disease progression, the development of motor complications termed L-DOPA-induced dyskinesia (LID). LID is the result of profound modifications in the functional organization of the basal ganglia circuitry. There is increasing evidence of the involvement of non-dopaminergic systems on the pathophysiology of LID. This raises the possibility of novel promising therapeutic approaches in the future, including agents that interfere with glutamatergic, serotonergic, adenosine, adrenergic, and cholinergic neurotransmission that are currently in preclinical testing or clinical development. Herein, we summarize the current knowledge of the pharmacology of LID in PD. More importantly, this review attempts to highlight the role of nitric oxide (NO) in PD and provide a comprehensive picture of recent preclinical findings from our group and others showing its potential involvement in dyskinesia.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Spinal cord injury (SCI) results in major motor, sensory, and autonomic dysfunction. Patients with SCI typically have permanent devastating neurologic deficits. Besides since SCI incidence is rising, as well as life expectancy, it is estimated that there are approximately 3 million patients with SCI worldwide. The main causes are motor vehicle accidents (36-48%), violence (5-29%), leisure activities (7-16%), falls and injuries from firearms (17-21%). Epidemiological studies estimate that SCI occurs mainly in men (81%) aged between 16 and 30 years, i.e., the most productive period of his life. In the initial phase of the injury, known as spinal shock, the motor innervation and visceral vessels remain silent. During the decline of the spinal shock, (4-6 weeks), the pathological reflexes and spasticity may develop due to lack of supraspinal control. Much of the SCI is due to secondary events that occur from minutes to weeks after the primary lesion induced by spinal cord contusion. The altered cellular mechanisms that take place during the secondary lesion are not fully understood, representing a dynamic and complex challenge. Cell injury mobilizes a sequence of molecular and cellular responses that may increase the severity of the injury. Among them are: changes in blood flow, edema, accumulation of intracellular calcium and potassium in the extracellular space, hydrolysis of phospholipids, formation of free radicals, release of excitatory amino acids such as glutamate and aspartate, migration of inflammatory cells, activation of microglia, the presence of inhibitory growth factors, among others mediators. Despite relatively large knowledge of these mediators and mechanisms, to date no available treatment to the complete healing of victims of SCI exists. Attempts to alleviate damage may include pharmacological interventions that are important in reducing injury. In acute traumatic SCI the effects of glucocorticoids administered immediately after the injury showed impr

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
A presente inveno situa-se no campo da Terapia Gnica de distrbios neurolgicos descrevendo estruturas genticas capazes de causar interferncia de RNA (RNAi) sobre a enzima xido ntrico sintase neuronal (nNOS), visando a teraputica
10 de distrbios neurolgicos degenerativos ou neoplsicos. Tratam-se de estruturas sintticas de RNAs curtos em dupla fita (duplex e grampos de RNA) e de insertos para vetores de expresso, capazes de alterar o contedo do RNAm da nNOS e de causar, em consequncia, efeitos desejados de reduo da viabilidade de clulas tumorais e da melhora da viabilidade de clulas neuronais submetidas a injria. As estruturas genticas para RNAi em nNOS so capazes de produzir efeitos desejados em dois modelos experimentais distintos, clulas tumorais de glioma e a clula dopaminrgica
20 SH-SY5Y. Essa linhagem celular SH-SY5Y tem sido utilizada como modelo ?in vitro? de Parkinson, uma vez que apresenta vrios fentipos de clula neuronal dopaminrgica e, alm disto, responde aos mesmos tratamentos utilizados nos modelos ?in vivo? desta doena, diante de diferentes injrias qumicas (Xie et al. Chin Med J 123:1086-1092, 2010). Essas estruturas genticas atuam reduzindo a viabilidade de clulas tumorais de glioma em cultura e, tambm, aumentando a viabilidade de clulas dopaminrgicas SH-SY5Y submetidas injria qumica. Os construtos do presente invento tm uso potencial na teraputica de distrbios oncolgicos - em particular quando associados aos agentes pr-apoptticos neomicina e interferon gama (INF-), assim como no tratamento de doenas crnico- degenerativas a exemplo do Parkinson.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES:
A presente inveno refere-se a construtos de nucleotdeos, denominados de duplex, grampos e insertos capazes de promover interferncia de RNA sobre o RNA mensageiro (RNAm) da enzima xido ntrico sintase neuronal
10 (nNOS), reduzindo a sua expresso. Adicionalmente a inveno tambm se refere a um mtodo para inibio da expresso do RNAm da enzima nNOS que causa, em consequncia, efeitos de reduo da viabilidade de clulas tumorais de glioma e melhora da viabilidade de clulas dopaminrgicas submetidas a injria.
15 Outro aspecto da inveno consiste na utilizao dos insertos para clonagem e expresso em vetores plasmidiais visando a obteno de RNAs capazes de provocar interferncia de RNA sobre a enzima nNOS. Alm disso, os construtos da inveno uma vez utilizados em associao com neomicina e INF-
20 mostram potencial para tratamento de distrbios neurolgicos.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
A presente inveno descreve uma composio farmacutica
contendo Canabidiol sinttico, Canabidiol de origem vegetal,
canabinides ou associao entre estes ou outros frmacos
indicados para transtornos neurolgicos, bem como os principais
excipientes utilizados no processo produtivo, alm do seu processo
de preparo em pequena, mdia e larga escala e sua utilizao para o
tratamento de distrbios neurolgicos em populao humana ou
animal, em especial no tratamento da doena de Parkinson, em
doses dirias de 100 a 1750 mg, preferencialmente na faixa de 400 a
850 mg/dia.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Parkinson?s disease (PD) is a chronic and progressive neurobiological disorder affecting millions of people worldwide. PD is a progressive multisystem disease associated with motor (e.g., bradykinesia, tremor, rigidity and postural instability) and non-motor deficiencies. It includes impaired olfaction, gastrointestinal, genitourinary, cardiovascular and respiratory dysfunctions, sleep, sensory, visual and neuropsychiatric disorders. Although pharmacotherapy of the symptoms is complex, several pharmacological compounds can alleviate motor and non-motor symptoms of PD. 
Today, L-DOPA (L-3,4‐dihydroxyphenylalanine) is the most effective and best- tolerated therapy for PD Unfortunately, L‐DOPA (also referred to as Levodopa) treatment tends to fade with time. Treatment of patients may have to be suspended because of its side effects, which can include motor function fluctuations, dyskinesia (i.e., abnormal involuntary movements) and psychiatric problems. Hyperkinetic choreiform and/or dystonic abnormal involuntary movements characterize L‐DOPA‐induced dyskinesia (LID). 
Nowadays, the understanding of the mechanisms underlying the development of LID is only poorly understood, and consequently, no effective treatment exists for limiting LID development in PD patients.
There is thus currently an important need for molecules that may treat LID.
In the present invention, the Applicant demonstrates that tetracycline compounds, in particular doxycycline, minocycline and derivatives thereof, such as, for example, chemically modified tetracycline-3 (CMT), efficiently treat in a rat model of L-DOPA-induced dyskinesia.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Symposium description 

This symposium will discuss cutting-edge research on psychoses in four diverse countries. Most psychiatric research is conducted in a few high-income countries with study participants of European background. Such limitations curtail the benefit of study findings to populations globally. Research across diverse contexts and peoples is essential for complete understanding of psychoses and for developing effective treatments for all. Consider that environmental exposures differ within and between countries; associations between urban living and psychosis are not observed in developing countries, for example. Growing evidence that poverty, deprivation, and social inequity increase risk for, and outcomes of, psychosis make research in diverse settings crucial for advancing psychiatric science and addressing diverse treatment needs. Additionally, some non-Western countries offer traditional remedies that may lead to efficacious treatments for populations worldwide. 

Psychiatric research is challenging in many countries due to inadequacies in funding, staff training, time, and research infrastructure. Facing these and other challenges, women scientists offer unique perspectives on conducting research and establishing successful professional careers. This symposium will present cutting-edge psychosis research, interwoven with gender-related challenges in four diverse countries. The speakers will discuss their research and the challenges they faced and overcame:

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Report on VLTP course given at University of Costa Rica, San Jose, Costa Rica, January 14-22, 2004, organized by Jaime Fornaguera and U. J. McMahan
Prepared by U. J. McMahan (Chair, VLTP) and John Nicholls
DESCRIPTION: The aim of the course was to provide students, teachers, research workers and medical clinicians in neuroscience in Costa Rica and from nearby countries with a forum for the detailed discussion of both specific topics of current interest in the field and opportunities for career development. It consisted of 37 lectures (50 min) on classical and modern principles of neuroscience plus 6 small-group discussion/conferences (1hr) on. There were also six tutorials (1 hr) on how to present 10-min research talks at international meetings. The course extended over nine days: seven were lecture days, one (in the middle) was a free day and one (the last) was for the 10-min talks by the students, research lectures by local faculty in the neurosciences, and a discussion of training opportunities abroad including those funded by the NIH, the Grass Foundation, the Wellcome Trust, and various German agencies. 
ministradas: Overview of Molecular Neurobiology, Experimental Parkinson's disease
There were six lecturers: Professor John Nicholls (SISSA, Italy), Professor Elaine del Bel (University of Sao Paolo, Brazil), Professor Lawrence Cohen (Yale University Medical School, US), Alasdair Gibb (University College London, UK), Walter Sthmer (Max-Planck Institute for Experimental Medicine-Goettingen, Germany) and Jack McMahan (Stanford University School of Medicine, US). The lectures included mechanisms of synaptic transmission and sensory transduction; the structure and function of channels, receptors and pumps; the structural, functional organization of the vertebrate olfactory and visual systems; steps and mechanisms in neural development and regeneration, and the molecular basis of certain diseases. It was particularly fortunate that Elaine del Bel from Ribeirao

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
IBRO COURSE IN NEUROSCIENCE: Makerere University
February 16-24, 2005
Organizers: Professor Ebuk Moses, Makerere University, Kampala, Uganda. 
 Professor Uel Jackson McMahan, Stanford University School of Medicine, USA.
Lecturers: 
Philippe Ascher, University Denis Diderot, Paris, France,
Elaine Del Bel, Department of Physiology, University of Sao Paulo, Ribeirao Preto, Brazil.
Alasdair Gibb, Department of Pharmacology, University College London, UK.
Yuan Liu, National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke, NIH, Bethesda, Maryland, USA.
Jack McMahan, Department of Neurobiology, Stanford University, Stanford, California, USA.
Kenneth Muller, Department of Physiology and Biophysics, University of Miami School of Medicine. USA.
John Nicholls, SISSA, Trieste, Italy.

Thirty-eight lectures last for about 50 minutes each. Conferences are used for discussion of questions that arise from the lectures and consist of small groups that rotate day by day to different instructors. Students will have the opportunity to discuss and prepare 10 min.talks and abstracts on their own work if they wish. Tutorials on how to present the talks and abstracts are given at the end of each day. There will also be a discussions about studentships and postdoctoral opportunities in Europe, and North America .

IBRO WORKSHOP IN NEUROSCIENCE: University of Nairobi
February 12 & 13, 2005

Organizers: Nilesh Patel, Professor, Department of Physiology, University of Nairobi Faculty of Medicine.
 Emily Kuria, Student, University of Nairobi.
	Uel Jackson McMahan, Professor, Stanford University School of Medicine, USA.

Lecturers: 
Elaine del Bel, Department of Physiology, University of Sao Paulo, Ribeirao Preto, Brazil. <eadelbel@forp.usp.br>
Jack McMahan, Department of Neurobiology, Stanford University, Stanford, California, USA. <grantser@stanford.edu>
John Nicholls, SISSA, Trieste, Italy. <nicholls@sissa.it>

Twelve lectures will last for about 50 minutes each. Discussions will concern lecture content as well as studentships and postdoctoral opportunities in Europe, and North America .

 9:00 Signaling. (JN)
10:00 Coffee/tea break

11:30 Break
11:45 The impact of molecular biology on neuroscience. (EdB)
12:45 Lunch

 3:00 Coffee/tea break

 4;15 Break
 4:30 Correlating function and gene expression. (EdB).
 5:30 Discussion.

Sunday, February 13, 2005.
 9:00 Nitric oxide: a gas as a transmitter in the CNS. (EdB) 
10:00 Coffee break

11:30 Break
11:45 Molecular composition of the synaptic cleft and postsynaptic apparatus.(JM) 
12:45 Lunch

 3:00 Coffee/tea break

 4:15 Break

 5:30 Discussion

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
By Paul Bolam (Oxford University) editor of the European Journal of Neuroscience

SUBJECT: The Publishing of Scientific Papers
Data: October 11 and 13 from.
Topics to be covered: 
1.	How a paper is handled once submitted to a journal 
2.	What happens to your paper?
3.	The ?peer-review? system
4.	What the Editors do
5.	What the Reviewers do
6.	Exercise: Looking a ?good? and ?bad? reviews
7.	How to respond to Reviewers? comments
8.	Ethics of publishing (human subjects, animals, plagiarism)
9.	What we expect in a good paper
10.	Exercise: Looking at ?good? and ?bad? abstracts
Give a paper for the students to review, they send it to me at a later date and I then provide feedback. This was not taken up by anyone on the last occasion.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Neurocientista atende convite do Senado Federal e apresenta resultados de pesquisa com droga amplamente conhecida, a doxiciclina

Elaine Del Bel, professora da Faculdade de Odontologia de Ribeiro Preto (FORP) da USP, participou dia 12 de maro de audincia pblica, no Senado Federal, para debater A instituio do ms de abril como o ms da conscientizao sobre a Doena de Parkinson.

Especialista em bioqumica, farmacologia e fisiologia do sistema nervoso central, a neurocientista da USP lidera um grupo de pesquisa que tem obtido sucesso em modelos experimentais de tratamento para a doena de Parkinson. Elaine atendeu ao convite da Comisso de Direitos Humanos e Legislao Participativa do Senado que reuniu autoridades pblicas, especialistas mdicos, ONGs e representante do Ministrio da Sade. O objetivo da audincia agilizar aes que minimizem sofrimento causado pela doena ainda sem cura.

E em abril, no dia 11, comemorado o Dia Mundial de Conscientizao da Doena de Parkinson, data de nascimento do cirurgio ingls James Parkinson que em 1817 foi o primeiro a relatar um caso da doena que agride msculos e nervos de maneira progressiva. O mal piora ao longo da vida, intensificando sintomas como tremores incontrolveis, rigidez de membros, diminuio de equilbrio, coordenao e movimentos. Doena tambm marca pela dor, confuso, ansiedade, depresso e demncia.

A professora Elaine foi uma das primeiras a falar na audincia. Relatou os ltimos achados dos estudos de sua equipe, especialmente com a doxiciclina, um antibitico barato e amplamente conhecido. A apresentao pode ser acessada no site do Senado Federal.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-PROGRAMA-DE-RADIO-OU-TV.TITULO: Professora da USP apresenta avanos das pesquisas sobre Parkinson na Cmara Federal

DETALHAMENTO-DO-PROGRAMA-DE-RADIO-OU-TV.TEMA: Doena de Parkinsonn

AUTORES.NOME-COMPLETO-DO-AUTOR: Elaine Aparecida Del Bel Belluz Guimaraes

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Desta vez foi a Cmara Federal que conheceu a investigao cientfica e o futuro promissor do tratamento do Parkinson. A professora Elaine Del Bel (foto), da Faculdade de Odontologia de Ribeiro Preto (FORP) da USP, foi recebida no incio de junho pelos deputados federais e pblico presente. Em maro, Elaine j havia apresentado ao Senado Federal, em audincia pblica da Comisso de Direitos Humanos para Conscientizao sobre a Doena de Parkinson.

Neurodegenerativa e incapacitante, a doena atinge cerca de 200 mil pessoas no Brasil. No mundo, 1% da populao com idade superior a 65 anos est afetada. Apresenta como sintomas mais comuns tremores e rigidez muscular; mas como progressiva passa dos problemas motores para os de memria e do sistema nervoso, chegando demncia. E, o pior: ainda no tem cura.

O convite para apresentao na Cmara Federal foi da Comisso de Defesa dos Direitos das Pessoas com Deficincia. Desta vez, a pesquisadora falou sobre a importncia das mentes preparadas dos pesquisadores e os rumos promissores de um possvel tratamento para o Parkinson, os testes com a doxiciclina.

Droga amplamente usada como antibitico, a doxiciclina foi descoberta como alternativa teraputica para a doena quando, administrada por engano juntamente com a rao a animais de laboratrio com Parkinson, conseguiu barrar a evoluo do mal.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
A professora da USP foi premiada pelo grande nmero de estudantes que orientou em seus anos de docncia! 👊

De famlia simples, ela cresceu em Santa Rita do Passa Quatro, se mudou sozinha para Ribeiro quando tinha 19 anos, pelo sonho de estudar! 👊

Um caminho para o controle do Parkinson resultado de uma de suas pesquisas! Pela sua histria de luta, decidiu abrir portas para os alunos!🙅‍♀

DADOS-BASICOS-DE-ORIENTACOES-CONCLUIDAS-.TITULO: O Sistema do xido Ntrico nas Glndulas Salivares de Ratos tratados com Isoproterenol

DETALHAMENTO-DE-ORIENTACOES-CONCLUIDAS-P.NOME-DO-ORIENTADO: Ana Carolina de Castro Issy Pereira
DETALHAMENTO-DE-ORIENTACOES-CONCLUIDAS-P.NOME-DA-INSTITUICAO: Universidade de So Paulo
DETALHAMENTO-DE-ORIENTACOES-CONCLUIDAS-P.NOME-DA-AGENCIA: Coordenao de Aperfeioamento de Pessoal de Nvel Superior

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: As glndulas salivares alm dos neurotransmissores clssicos, substncias vasoativas, fatores de crescimento podem sofrer a ao de neuromoduladores incluindo o xido ntrico (NO). O NO est presente na saliva, parece desempenhar na cavidade oral atividade de proteo exercida por sua atuao bactericida, h indcios de participao no controle neural da secreo salivar, alm de ser importante fator em doenas orais. Nas glndulas salivares de ratos a ativao dos receptores noradrenrgicos, pela exposio crnica ao agonista Isoproterenol, promove o crescimento das glndulas partida e submandibular bem como aumento da sntese de NO. Esse fenmeno foi descrito por Selye (Nature: 45, 3-10, 1961), relacionado ao crescimento das glndulas salivares de prisioneiros de campos de concentrao durante a segunda grande guerra, tendo sido atribudo ao stress e ou desnutrio. O mecanismo de hipertrofia das glndulas induzida por Isoproterenol ainda no foi completamente esclarecido. Nossa hiptese pelo acima descrito de que o NO participe do controle neural da secreo salivar e os Objetivos deste trabalho so estudar a influncia do NO na secreo salivar, analisando a enzima NOS no tecido das glndulas salivares maiores (partidas, submandibulares e sublinguais) de ratos. A estratgia experimental utilizada e portanto nossos objetivos especficos so: i.comparar a atividade NOS no tecido das glndulas salivares de animais inocentes e aps tratamento com agonista *-noradrenrgico Isoproterenol e ii. analisar se o efeito do Isoproterenol pode ser inibido pelo tratamento concomitante com inibidores da sntese do NO.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Coordenador: Prof Vincent Torre (SISSA-Itlia) Europe and Latin America have a very similar cultural background and share a common historical heritage. The present proposal aims at strengthening scientific collaborations and research partnerships between research institutions in Europe and in Latin America, in key emerging fields of contemporary science and in particular in ? Neuroscience ? Biophysics and Molecular Neurobiology ? Bionanotechnology and Genomics The proposal gathers well-known Institutes in Latin America and Europe with distinct but complementary scientific interests and experience. This project, therefore, covers broad areas in the above disciplines and is designed to: ? provide a forum for the exchange of staff and young students and researchers among these institutions ? foster scientific collaborations among more senior scientists ? provide opportunities to pursue specific projects in these key emerging area fields Proposed scientific exchanges and collaborations are expected to develop more open-minded scientists, able to carry out at the same time original and competitive studies and to participate with success in the development of research and high standard training in underdeveloped areas. Taken as a whole, institutions participating in the present proposal offer a panel of understanding, know-how, specific experience, technology and interactions with external entities - many of which of biotechnological nature - that is not common in Europe and Latin America. The proposal, therefore, covers broad areas in the above disciplines and is designed to give young researchers and students in the early stages of their carrier, common general and advanced background training, as well as opportunities to pursue specific projects in areas they intend to specialize in during their subsequent professional life.
